items.title: Amend the pypi.org docs
items.body:
Sorry to post it here. I checked if I could amend directly the docs at pypi but did not find the way. Am available to do it myself if you point me in the right direction.

In the [pypy docs](https://pypi.org/project/textstat/) it (still?) signals to use `textstat.set_language(lang)` instead that the correct `textstat.set_lang(lang)`. 

In addition or as substitute to changing the docs maybe placing an alias with `textstat.set_language` pointing to `textstat.set_lang(lang)` would work as well?

Hope this helps

items.title: Flesch-Kincaid Grade Level
items.body: The documentation explains that the code "Returns the Flesch-Kincaid Grade of the given text. This is a grade formula in that a score of 9.3 means that a ninth grader would be able to read the document."  But when I run the code on text I have, the scores are all in the 90s.  Indeed, the results are very similar to the Flesch Reading Ease Score.  Am I doing something wrong, or is there an error in the code that it is not producing the grade level.

items.title: Conda release
items.body:
Will require conda to be installed, the minimal installer can be found here: https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/miniconda.html. After installation, turn off auto base with `conda config --set auto_activate_base false`.

Tutorial for building packages here: https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda-build/en/latest/user-guide/tutorials/build-pkgs.html

items.body: See https://github.com/DaveChild/Text-Statistics

items.title: Dropped Python 2 support
items.body:
Python 2 end of life is fast approaching. https://pythonclock.org/.

Textstat currently supports Python 2 and 3. However, the plan will be to drop support for Python 2 at some point. This means some compatibility code can be removed.

- [x] Replace [`repoze.lru`](https://github.com/repoze/repoze.lru) with builtin [`functools.lru_cache`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functools.html#functools.lru_cache) (#100).

items.title: Allow to change language in syllable_count to languages supported by Pyphen
items.body: Currently syllable_count takes a lang argument which is set to 'en_US' by default. This can be changed to take lang argument input during function call. Pyphen allows for many language options. Some of the languages used might be effected by having a different sentence delimited other than a period but it should work for some cases and further improvement can be made.

items.title: text-stat standard (label documentation).
items.body:
text-stat `standard` can attain very high values ie 40 or more. Since the standard metric is probably no longer informative about reading level, do you think it makes sense to describe it as a measure of 'cognitive-load' associated with decoding the text? 
See 1st plot of distributions here:
https://github.com/russelljjarvis/ScienceAccessibility

items.title: Question about the code correctness? PDF text extraction and readability index(gunning fog)
items.body:
Hi everyone
I am doing a readability (fog index) to a PDF (academic paper). I extract the text of PDF (all pages) and then I try to transfer the context direct into readability code. But I do not think I am correct, because the index I got is 9.69, which is too low I think. I use the example in Github, much easier one, and got 12. Can anyone help me to check the code? many thanks

```python
import PyPDF2
pdfName = "C:\\Users\\Liuruohan\\.spyder-py3\\peer.pdf"
read_pdf = PyPDF2.PdfFileReader(pdfName)

for i in range(read_pdf.getNumPages()):
    page = read_pdf.getPage(i)
    print ('Page No - ' + str(1+read_pdf.getPageNumber(page)))
    page_content = page.extractText()
    print (page_content)

import textstat
test_data = page_content
textstat.gunning_fog(test_data)
```

#I do not know what should I put behind the test_data, and is my first part correct?(I want to extract text from all pages)#

Many thanks

items.title: Post-Modern Essay Generator scores low on Standard reading level when contrasted with more sensible documents (label -philosophical problem)
items.body:
As the title of this issue suggests Post-Modern Essay Generator counter-intuitively scores low on Standard reading level compared to other sensible documents. If I have not made a mistake, and the [PMEG](http://www.elsewhere.org/pomo/) really does require a relatively [low](https://github.com/russelljjarvis/ScienceAccessibility)  reading level compared to other mainstream science articles. If this result is true, then it violates intuition about readability since the PMEG produces very coded and obscure output. Because the PMEG is a different document each time you access it, I get the [mean standard value over 10 samples](https://github.com/russelljjarvis/ScienceAccessibility/blob/dev/SComplexity/get_bmark_corpus.py#L66-#L77).

I wonder if there is scope to add an information theory based readability metric to the standard reading level? Such as checking the compression ratio, of the text [encoded as a string](https://github.com/russelljjarvis/ScienceAccessibility/blob/dev/SComplexity/utils.py#L76-L84
)? Or by using [perplexity](https://github.com/russelljjarvis/ScienceAccessibility/blob/dev/SComplexity/t_analysis.py#L40-L60)?

You can think of these approaches as creating a word histogram of a document, and then yielding information about how improbable the observed word frequency histogram was. Perplexity just looks at the unigram term frequency distribution, however, I think LZW, might work by minimizing redundancy associated with sensed reoccurring N-grams, such that the decompression ratio, is sensitive to the likely hood of phrases.

I think an information theory approach could be more robust, and more appropriately penalize documents with highly obscure wording. I just don't have any ideas yet, about how to map the outputs of these algorithms, so the ranges returned map onto appropriate reading grade levels. 

I wonder if anyone has any ideas about this approach?

items.title: Grammarly integration (label proposed feature)
items.body:
Although Grammarly is a commercial product (with a paid premium, free basic business model), its based on an [open source tool-chain.](https://github.com/grammarly)

I think the impact of textstat on scientific writing will be better if Grammarly gave live updates about the grade reading level of paragraphs. Of course, it would be better if it was a part of something like Grammarly that was completely free to use.

As I need to calculate them at corpus level, I am passing the entire content of the text file to these functions. I am wondering if instead I should compute them at sentence level and then average for all sentences in the file? Can you please advise which is the way to go? Thanks!

items.title: Reading time
items.body:
It'd be nice to be able to calculate reading time. There are a lot of articles that put adults words per minute at 200-275.

https://marketingland.com/estimated-reading-times-increase-engagement-79830
https://blog.medium.com/read-time-and-you-bc2048ab620c
http://www.craigabbott.co.uk/how-to-calculate-reading-time-like-medium

There's the possibility to just have a `textstat.reading_time(words_per_minute=200)`, which is simple.

It'd be nice to have `reading_time` be based on the complexity of the text though!

There are a few of papers I found (I haven't read them yet) that might provide some insight.

> Ronald P. Carver (1976) Word Length, Prose Difficulty, and Reading Rate
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/10862967609547176

> Ronald P. Carver (1989) Silent Reading Rates in Grade Equivalents 
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/10862968909547667

> Keith Rayner, Elizabeth R. Schotter, Michael E. J. Masson, Mary C. Potter, and Rebecca Treiman (2016) So Much to Read, So Little Time: How Do We Read, and Can Speed Reading Help?
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/1529100615623267

items.title: Add the SPACHE readability formula for young readers
items.body:
Need to add the SPACHE readability formula for young readers.

Details here: http://www.readabilityformulas.com/spache-readability-formula.php

---

1. Select a sample text of 100-150 words from a primary grade level text.
2. Count the total number of words in the sample text.
3. Count the number of sentences in the sample text.
4. Divide the figure obtained in Step 2 by the figure obtained in Step 3 to arrive at Average Sentence Length (ASL)
5. Count the number of words in the sample text that are not found on the Spache Revised Word List (as revised in 1974).
6. Divide the figure obtained in Step 5 with the figure obtained in Step 2, and multiply the result by 100, to arrive at Percentage of Difficult Words (PDW).
7. Compute the Spache Readability Index with the following formula:

Spache Readability Index/Grade Level = `(0.141 * ASL) + (0.086 * PDW) + 0.839`

where,

`ASL` = Average Sentence Length

`PDW` = Percentage of Difficult Words

items.title: Add the new Dale-Chall readability formula
items.body:
Need to add the new Dale-Chall formula. Not sure what to call the method. Seems silly to call it `new_dale_chall_readability_score()`. 🤔 

Details here: http://www.readabilityformulas.com/new-dale-chall-readability-formula.php

---

Compute the following equation:
- Raw Score = 0.1579 * (PDW) + 0.0496 * ASL
- Raw Score = Reading Grade of a reader who can comprehend your text at 3rd grade or below.
- PDW = Percentage of Difficult Words
- ASL = Average Sentence Length in words
- If (PDW) is greater than 5%, then:
  - Adjusted Score = Raw Score + 3.6365,
- otherwise
   - Adjusted Score = Raw Score
- Adjusted Score = Reading Grade of a reader who can comprehend your text at 4th grade or above.
- Use the following table to get the Adjusted Grade Level:

| ADJUSTED SCORE | GRADE LEVEL                            |
|----------------|----------------------------------------|
| 4.9 and Below  | Grade 4 and Below                      |
| 5.0 to 5.9     | Grades 5 - 6                           |
| 6.0 to 6.9     | Grades 7 - 8                           |
| 7.0 to 7.9     | Grades 9 - 10                          |
| 8.0 to 8.9     | Grades 11 - 12                         |
| 9.0 to 9.9     | Grades 13 - 15 (College)               |
| 10 and Above   | Grades 16 and Above (College Graduate) |

Hey there,

i think there is a counting problem with the Avg letter per Word.

Code 
`textstat.avg_letter_per_word("﻿thisissued percent .")`

So the result is:

I expected:

There are 17 letters and two words. So 17/2 = 8,5.
I think avg_letter... count the **first** spaces and punctuation as letters.

I tried it with the Text `"﻿thisissued          percent                ."` (Here are 10 Spaces between each word, but i cant show it inhere)
and also get the result 
> 9.5

Thanks for help.

Richard

items.title: Extended ASCII set - UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte
items.body:
Many of these functions (such as `textstat.flesch_kincaid_grade`) cannot handle ascii characters outside the first 128. Even in English text, there are occasionally characters in the extended ascii set that will appear, such as the sentence 'She spent ¥130' which when run:  `textstat.flesch_kincaid_grade('She spent ¥130')` produces the error `UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc2 in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)`

Can you please extend the ascii set or provide another plausible solution so the program doesn't break at unexpected non-English characters?

items.title: Issue with Gunning Fog Calculation
items.body: I believe is an error in the Gunning Fog Calculation. There should not be an addition of 5 to per_diff_words.

items.title: Lexicon count is incorrect
items.body:
The `lexicon_count` of the `long_test` in the tests is currently incorrect. It is incorrectly counting the "..." as a word because there is a space either side.

The word count of the `long_test` should be 375, not 376.

items.title: Sentence count is incorrect
items.body:
The current regex for splitting sentences doesn't work for all cases.

The `long_test` actually has 16 sentences, but the regex split is creating a list with a length of 21, and the `sentence_count` function is returning 17 after filtering out items with a word count less than 2.

The current regex needs the last `*` replacing with a look ahead for a capital letter.

### Current 
`' *[\.\?!][\'"\)\]]  * *'`

[![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13941027/43128740-ad0232f2-8f2a-11e8-96cf-9d93bd33b7b3.png)](https://regex101.com/r/lJ7qa9/1/)

### Proposed 
`' *[\.\?!]['\"\)\]]* (?=[A-Z])'`

[![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13941027/43128785-c88907c6-8f2a-11e8-97f2-b2b3595791a9.png)](https://regex101.com/r/CK8sjB/1/)

items.title: README fixes
items.body:
I've opened this issue to discuss some changes to the README following #44.

I really like the style of README found in kennethreitz projects. Examples in [maya](https://github.com/kennethreitz/maya), [requests](https://github.com/requests/requests), and my own 😊 [specsavers](https://github.com/alxwrd/specsavers).

The general style is:
```markdown
# Title
explanation

## Useage
example code

## Installing
details on how to install

## More details
some more information about the project, textstat could have the function documentation here

## Contributing
details on how to contribute to the project.
```

@shivam5992  I'd like your thoughts on this style of README?

If there wasn't a full style overhaul, a couple things I've noticed with the current README:

- [x] Some headers are at the wrong level (## vs ###)
- [x] A couple of typos (`The The Flesch-Kincaid Grade Level`)
- [x] I think it would be nice if there were reference/further info links for all the formulas.

items.title: Documented import does not work
items.body:
The current instructions in `README.md` say

    import textstat

However, this doesn't bring in the module.  I am presently forced to use

    from textstat.textstat import textstat

The final `textstat` is a package-global instance of the internal class `textstatistics` which is a slightly odd design.

A common solution is to encapsulate this in the package's `__init__.py`

items.title: Different behavior between 0.3.1 and 0.4.1
items.body:
I have noticed that 0.3.1 and 0.4.1 have quite different behaviors for certain functions. The following is the comparison on flesch_reading_ease:

Version 0.3.1:
`from textstat.textstat import textstat`
`textstat.flesch_reading_ease("Python package to calculate statistics from text to determine readability, complexity and grade level of a particular corpus.")`
`>> 10.91`

Version 0.4.1:
`from textstat.textstat import textstat `
`textstat.flesch_reading_ease("Python package to calculate statistics from text to determine readability, complexity and grade level of a particular corpus.")`
`>> 19.37`

My guess is that this is from the change in calculating syllabuses, but I am not sure until I dig thoroughly through the commit history. Have you noticed this behavior? Is there an interpretation?

It seems to me that 0.4.1's calculation is more robust / scientific. But it would be good to maintain backward compatibility during version updates.  Is there, or do you plan to develop, an option in 0.4.x that allows users to regenerate the results in 0.3.1?

items.title: Including RIX equations
items.body:
Adding these two measurements would make textstat more feature-full.
LIX: https://github.com/mmautner/readability/blob/master/readability.py#L73
RIX: https://github.com/mmautner/readability/blob/master/readability.py#L83
Reference: https://github.com/mmautner/readability

items.title: default-returns in functions
items.body:
Hi @alxwrd, 

Many functions are missing default returns. For example, the avg_sentence_length function returns None when the number of sentences is zero. I think we need to add default return values in these functions. For example 0.0 

I believe that this is important because when someone is trying to use these package in pandas like the following and running this function for a large number of rows if any row is empty.

`df['flesch_reading_ease'] = df[col].apply(textstat.flesch_reading_ease)
`

Then they will get the error. Let me know what do you think.

items.title: Linsear Write misses words that are 3 syllables long
items.body:
In the `linsear_write_formula` function, if a word has 3 syllables it won't be counted towards the score.

```python
    if self.syllable_count(value) < 3:
        easy_word.append(value)
    elif self.syllable_count(value) > 3:
        difficult_word.append(value)
```

From [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linsear_Write):

> 1. Find a 100-word sample from your writing.
> 2. Calculate the **easy words (defined as two syllables or less)** and place a number "1" over each word, even including a, an, the, and other simple words.
> 3. Calculate the **hard words (defined as three syllables or more)** and place a number "3" over each word as pronounced by the dictionary.
> 4. Multiply the number of easy words times "1."
> 5. Multiply the number of hard words times "3."
> 6. Add the two previous numbers together.
> 7. Divide that total by the number of sentences.
> 8. If your answer is >20, divide by "2," and that is your answer.
> 9. If your answer is <20 or equal to 20, subtract "2," and then divide by "2." That is your answer.

items.title: difficult_words bugs like case-sensitivity and marks at the end of sentence
items.body:
def difficult_words(self, text)
extracts the words by simply splitting the text by using spaces. but this can lead to a condition that "." (or other marks) be part of a word. For example, I input a sentence with word "lives." at end of it. Although "lives" is in the easy word list, it looks it as a difficult word. Another problem regarding this dot is that it sees paperwork. and paperwork as two different words which is not true
Another problem is case-sensitivity. This method sees Lives as a difficult word which is not true.
I suggest using a regex for extracting the words (if you want it to be stand-alone) or nltk if you want it to be perfect.

items.title: different results between similar packages
items.body:
Hi!

I've noticed that the results between textstat and the following package https://github.com/mmautner/readability

differ quite a bit! Any idea?
Thanks!

items.title: Returing wrong values!
items.body:
_The function "flesch_reading_ease" is returning a wrong value._ 

As per Wikipedia ([Click Here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flesch%E2%80%93Kincaid_readability_tests)) 

"The cat sat on the mat." should score 116 but, the function is returning "**124.61**" 

According to Wikipedia "The highest (easiest) readability score possible is **121.22**" 

I did not get a chance to evaluate the function but, this is my quick evaluation. Probably do it later! 

PS: Nice work! Loved the functions you have added in the package, Cheers.

to

items.title: function syllable_count returns a float value
items.body:
I find that syllable_count function returns non-integer result, and is always a multiple of 0.9
e.g. syllable_count('Hello') -> 1.8
e.g. syllable_count('how') -> 0.9
e.g. syllable_count('are') -> 0.9
e.g. syllable_count('you') -> 0.9
what does 0.9 syllable mean? shouldn't it be just 1 syllable

moreover, the syllable_count does not seem to follow the rule of summation, by calculating each word's syllable count, I expect the total syllable count of 'hello how are you' to be 1.8 + 0.9 + 0.9 + 0.9 = 4.5
but syllable_count('hello how are you') -> 5.4

Is this a common problem? Attached the screenshot as proof of the issue.
![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7760158/30574362-0254b2ee-9d2c-11e7-82b1-fbd9a7306dc8.PNG)

items.title: Hyphenation improvement
items.body:
Hyphenation as implemented in `textstat` works okay but not very well. Is there a particular reason for not using a dictionary-based hyphenation?
 [Pyphen](http://pyphen.org) for example is based on LibreOffice dictionaries and written in pure Python.

If you'd also see this as an improvement, I can make a pull request.

items.title: Performance issue when computing many readability features
items.body:
Thanks for your support and your tool can really help me do my research. But I also find performance problem when I compare your tool with another tool that compute readability characteristics of text named **readability**, especially when I must compute many readability features for the same text.

The python package **readability** requires user  first call its function `analyze_text`. After doing this step,
all base measurements that consume much time when they are computed such as number of words, number of sentences can be computed and temporarily stored.  By doing this, performance can be improved when someone want to compute many readability features at the same time.

But when I use **textstat** to compute readability features, some base features will be repeatedly computed. It is because needed base measurements are repeatedly computed in each function of **textstat**.

Hoping for your support!

Have a great week :)

Regards
Yuanrui

items.title: How can I compute LIX by using functions currently provided by textstat?
items.body:
Recently, I am doing a research on readability of some text files. Thanks for your package to help me compute characteristics of readability of the text files. But one feature called "LIX" is not found from current version of textstat. 

Although there are other packages that can help me compute this feature, I am a little confused about the accuracy when using different packages to compute the readability characteristics. Because I find that readability characteristic values computed by a package named "readability" are a little different from values computed by textstat.

Could you tell me how to compute the feature "LIX" simply from current functions provided by textstat or add this function to the library?

Thanks

items.title: Exception handling
items.body:
Hello, first of all great work, and thanks for sharing your library!

I want to comment on some of the things that are related to error handling in you code. There are a couple of small issues.

1)  At very least it is important to provide `Exception` class to the `except`

```
try:
    ...
except Exception:
    ...
```

If you don't provide `except Exception`, any kind of exception will be handled, including such as `KeyboardInterrupt`. Check https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#exception-hierarchy. If you make an error and spin up an infinite loop it might be difficult to kill it if you handle KeyboarInterrupt, and don't raise any error.

2) In most cases class passed to except should be as concrete as possible. For example in this case:

```
    def avg_letter_per_word(self, text):
        try:
            ALPW = float(float(self.char_count(text))/float(self.lexicon_count(text)))
            return round(ALPW, 2)
        except:
            print("Error(ALPW): Number of words are zero, cannot divide")
            return
```

a number of different things can go wrong inside `try ... except`. However In any case it just spits out `Number of words are zero`. This will make it very hard to debug issues. Much better would be:

```
try:
   ...
except ZeroDivisionError:
   ...
```

3) Instead of `print()` much better way to report errors is `raise Exception('... message ...)`, ideally with a custom exception class derived in your code.

items.title: count = count - (0.1*count)
items.body:
In syllable_count there is a "count = count - (0.1*count)" which will always make the syllable_count 10% smaller. So "Beautiful" returned 2.7. Is there a reason for this?

This function is called in polysyllabcount(), this will then only count syllables with more than 4 syllables in, which is not the definition of polysyllablecount

(I'm using python 3, I can't think of an immediate reason why this would just effect just python 3)

Hello

Could you provide the reference for difficult_words function of your library? Where do you take the formula?

Thank you very much,

items.title: Python 3 Compatability
items.body: `textstat` is not Python 3 compatible. I think the biggest problem is that it has old style print statements for errors, when these should either be new style print functions, or even better, thrown exceptions.

items.title: automated_readability_index should return nan on error?
items.body:
Hi,

I was wondering if automated_readability_index should be returning nan if there is an error. 

Thanks

`
basepath = os.path.dirname(__file__)
os.path.join(basepath, 'easy_word_list')
`

items.title: compatibility issue and dictionary comprehension usage
items.body:
Thanks for making this library available and for your time.

There's a minor compatibility issue with python 2.5 and 2.6 here:
https://github.com/shivam5992/textstat/blob/master/textstat/textstat.py#L222

That line uses a dictionary comprehension, which wasn't introduced until later python versions (2.7?).  It should be a simple change:  

old:
d = {x: grade.count(x) for x in grade}

new:
d = dict([(x, grade.count(x)) for x in grade])
